segment.source: 4688(S) A new process has been created.
segment.target: 4688(S) A new process has been created.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4688(S) A new process has been created.
segment.target: Describes security event 4688(S) A new process has been created.

segment.source: 4688(S): A new process has been created.
segment.target: 4688(S): A new process has been created.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time a new process starts.
segment.target: This event generates every time a new process starts.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions:
segment.target: Event Versions:

segment.source: 0 - Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: 0 - Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: 1 - Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows 8.1.
segment.target: 1 - Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows 8.1.

segment.source: Added “Process Command Line” field.
segment.target: Added “Process Command Line” field.

segment.source: 2 - Windows 10.
segment.target: 2 - Windows 10.

segment.source: Subject renamed to Creator Subject.
segment.target: Subject renamed to Creator Subject.

segment.source: Added “Target Subject” section.
segment.target: Added “Target Subject” section.

segment.source: Added “Mandatory Label” field.
segment.target: Added “Mandatory Label” field.

segment.source: Added “Creator Process Name” field.
segment.target: Added “Creator Process Name” field.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Creator Subject Value for versions 0 and 1 – Subject:
segment.target: Creator Subject Value for versions 0 and 1 – Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “create process” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “create process” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “create process” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “create process” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Target Subject Version 2:
segment.target: Target Subject Version 2:

segment.source: Note This event includes the principal of the process creator, but this is not always sufficient if the target context is different from the creator context.
segment.target: Note This event includes the principal of the process creator, but this is not always sufficient if the target context is different from the creator context.

segment.source: In that situation, the subject specified in the process termination event does not match the subject in the process creation event even though both events refer to the same process ID.
segment.target: In that situation, the subject specified in the process termination event does not match the subject in the process creation event even though both events refer to the same process ID.

segment.source: Therefore, in addition to including the creator of the process, we will also include the target principal when the creator and target do not share the same logon.
segment.target: Therefore, in addition to including the creator of the process, we will also include the target principal when the creator and target do not share the same logon.

segment.source: Security ID Type = SIDVersion 2: SID of target account.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SIDVersion 2: SID of target account.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeStringVersion 2: the name of the target account.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeStringVersion 2: the name of the target account.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeStringVersion 2: target account’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeStringVersion 2: target account’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64Version 2: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64Version 2: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Process Information:
segment.target: Process Information:

segment.source: New Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the new process.
segment.target: New Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the new process.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: New Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the new process.
segment.target: New Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the new process.

segment.source: Token Elevation Type Type = UnicodeString:
segment.target: Token Elevation Type Type = UnicodeString:

segment.source: TokenElevationTypeDefault (1): Type 1 is a full token with no privileges removed or groups disabled.
segment.target: TokenElevationTypeDefault (1): Type 1 is a full token with no privileges removed or groups disabled.

segment.source: A full token is only used if User Account Control is disabled or if the user is the built-in Administrator account (for which UAC disabled by default), service account or local system account.
segment.target: A full token is only used if User Account Control is disabled or if the user is the built-in Administrator account (for which UAC disabled by default), service account or local system account.

segment.source: TokenElevationTypeFull (2): Type 2 is an elevated token with no privileges removed or groups disabled.
segment.target: TokenElevationTypeFull (2): Type 2 is an elevated token with no privileges removed or groups disabled.

segment.source: An elevated token is used when User Account Control is enabled and the user chooses to start the program using Run as administrator.
segment.target: An elevated token is used when User Account Control is enabled and the user chooses to start the program using Run as administrator.

segment.source: An elevated token is also used when an application is configured to always require administrative privilege or to always require maximum privilege, and the user is a member of the Administrators group.
segment.target: An elevated token is also used when an application is configured to always require administrative privilege or to always require maximum privilege, and the user is a member of the Administrators group.

segment.source: TokenElevationTypeLimited (3): Type 3 is a limited token with administrative privileges removed and administrative groups disabled.
segment.target: TokenElevationTypeLimited (3): Type 3 is a limited token with administrative privileges removed and administrative groups disabled.

segment.source: The limited token is used when User Account Control is enabled, the application does not require administrative privilege, and the user does not choose to start the program using Run as administrator.
segment.target: The limited token is used when User Account Control is enabled, the application does not require administrative privilege, and the user does not choose to start the program using Run as administrator.

segment.source: Mandatory Label Version 2Type = SID: SID of integrity label which was assigned to the new process.
segment.target: Mandatory Label Version 2Type = SID: SID of integrity label which was assigned to the new process.

segment.source: Can have one of the following values:
segment.target: Can have one of the following values:

segment.source: SID
segment.target: SID

segment.source: RID
segment.target: RID

segment.source: RID label
segment.target: RID label

segment.source: Meaning
segment.target: Meaning

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYUNTRUSTEDRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYUNTRUSTEDRID

segment.source: Untrusted.
segment.target: Untrusted.

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYLOWRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYLOWRID

segment.source: Low integrity.
segment.target: Low integrity.

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYMEDIUMRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYMEDIUMRID

segment.source: Medium integrity.
segment.target: Medium integrity.

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYMEDIUMPLUSRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYMEDIUMPLUSRID

segment.source: Medium high integrity.
segment.target: Medium high integrity.

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYHIGHRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYHIGHRID

segment.source: High integrity.
segment.target: High integrity.

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYSYSTEMRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYSYSTEMRID

segment.source: System integrity.
segment.target: System integrity.

segment.source: SECURITYMANDATORYPROTECTEDPROCESSRID
segment.target: SECURITYMANDATORYPROTECTEDPROCESSRID

segment.source: Protected process.
segment.target: Protected process.

segment.source: Creator Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process which ran the new process.
segment.target: Creator Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process which ran the new process.

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Creator Process Name Version 2Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Creator Process Name Version 2Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Process Command Line Version 1, 2Type = UnicodeString: contains the name of executable and arguments which were passed to it.
segment.target: Process Command Line Version 1, 2Type = UnicodeString: contains the name of executable and arguments which were passed to it.

segment.source: You must enable “Administrative TemplatesSystemAudit Process CreationInclude command line in process creation events” group policy to include command line in process creation events:
segment.target: You must enable “Administrative TemplatesSystemAudit Process CreationInclude command line in process creation events” group policy to include command line in process creation events:

segment.source: By default Process Command Line field is empty.
segment.target: By default Process Command Line field is empty.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4688(S): A new process has been created.
segment.target: For 4688(S): A new process has been created.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor all events with the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor all events with the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor all events with the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor all events with the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” and “Target SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” and “Target SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.
segment.target: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” to see whether the account type is as expected.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” to see whether the account type is as expected.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).

segment.source: Monitor the specific events for the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.
segment.target: Monitor the specific events for the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.

segment.source: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “Creator SubjectSecurity ID” or “Target SubjectSecurity ID” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name” not equal to your defined value.
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name” not equal to your defined value.

segment.source: You can monitor to see if “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).
segment.target: You can monitor to see if “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name.”
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “NewProcess Name” or “Creator Process Name.”

segment.source: It can be unusual for a process to run using a local account in either Creator SubjectSecurity ID or in TargetSubjectSecurity ID.
segment.target: It can be unusual for a process to run using a local account in either Creator SubjectSecurity ID or in TargetSubjectSecurity ID.

segment.source: Monitor for Token Elevation Type with value TokenElevationTypeDefault (1) when SubjectSecurity ID lists a real user account, for example when Account Name doesn’t contain the $ symbol.
segment.target: Monitor for Token Elevation Type with value TokenElevationTypeDefault (1) when SubjectSecurity ID lists a real user account, for example when Account Name doesn’t contain the $ symbol.

segment.source: Typically this means that UAC is disabled for this account for some reason.
segment.target: Typically this means that UAC is disabled for this account for some reason.

segment.source: Monitor for Token Elevation Type with value TokenElevationTypeDefault (2) on standard workstations, when SubjectSecurity ID lists a real user account, for example when Account Name doesn’t contain the $ symbol.
segment.target: Monitor for Token Elevation Type with value TokenElevationTypeDefault (2) on standard workstations, when SubjectSecurity ID lists a real user account, for example when Account Name doesn’t contain the $ symbol.

segment.source: This means that a user ran a program using administrative privileges.
segment.target: This means that a user ran a program using administrative privileges.

segment.source: You can also monitor for Token Elevation Type with value TokenElevationTypeDefault (2) on standard workstations, when a computer object was used to run the process, but that computer object is not the same computer where the event occurs.
segment.target: You can also monitor for Token Elevation Type with value TokenElevationTypeDefault (2) on standard workstations, when a computer object was used to run the process, but that computer object is not the same computer where the event occurs.

segment.source: If you need to monitor all new processes with a specific Mandatory Label, for example S-1-16-20480 (Protected process), check the “Mandatory Label” in this event.
segment.target: If you need to monitor all new processes with a specific Mandatory Label, for example S-1-16-20480 (Protected process), check the “Mandatory Label” in this event.
